Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of Structural Testing System to Simulate Earthquake Loading

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration: This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) award supports the addition of two hydraulic actuators to an existing testing facility at Cal Poly to enable testing of various structural systems subject to extreme loading from natural hazards such as earthquakes. Much of the work has a high potential to directly impact codes and standardsâ€”leading to enhanced public safety. The instrumentation will enable fundamental research in four departments and will engage undergraduate and graduate students in research activities. The instrumentation will also be used for K-12 outreach activities in conjunction with Architecture Summer Career Workshop, Engineering Possibilities in College, and Design Village.<br/> <br/>The instrumentation will enable fundamental research to enhance the safety of the built environment by enabling cyclic in-plane lateral testing of structural systems with superimposed dead loads. The research activities range from large scale testing of reinforced concrete shear walls, to temperature-activated self-regulating facades and the response of masonry structures to severe natural hazards. The research projects will address fundamental knowledge gaps associated with the extreme loading for structural systems, such as potential fiber-reinforcing retrofits for pre-1980s reinforced concrete walls, the interaction of dynamic structural cladding with the underlying structure, stiffness in rigid wall-flexible diaphragm buildings and the design of new cross-laminated timber rocking shear wall systems.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

This Major Research Instrumentation award supports Cal Poly in San Luis Obispo with the acquisition of a hydraulic actuator system for research and education on the response of structural components when subjected to extreme loadings from natural hazards, particularly earthquakes. The actuator system provides automated control for simultaneous lateral and axial load with increased force and displacement capacity than previously available. Its capabilities have already enabled the investigation of novel design for high-strength plywood shear walls and a bolted steel moment frame connection with a replaceable ductile haunch. These experimental tests validate the performance of more economical, easily constructable, and well-performing options for structural design of buildings in seismic regions. Further studies using the actuator system are expected to address retrofit approaches of vintage reinforced concrete walls and the performance of a new base-isolation system, along with other research that will advance knowledge in the earthquake engineering of new and existing structures. Ultimately, work conducted in the laboratory with this actuator system will support increased resilience of building stock in earthquake-prone regions.

Broader Impact

This Major Research Instrumentation award provides Cal Poly in San Luis Obispo the ability to conduct large-scale structural tests that provide an avenue for mentorship of undergraduate and graduate students in structural design, construction, experimentation, analysis, and technical communication. In addition to senior and graduate projects, experiments using the actuator system are integrated in upper division courses exposing students to seismic response of existing structural systems and validating innovative design approaches that target identified industry challenges. These student and faculty research teams actively disseminate experimental findings to the earthquake engineering practitioners and educators via presentations at professional conferences as well as peer-reviewed publications. The teams also participate in public and K-12 outreach through events like the university’s Open House.

The acquisition of the actuator system has also led to increased collaboration with industry partners on more advanced projects and support for significant facility, hardware, and data acquisition upgrades in the laboratory. The research infrastructure enhancements enabled by the Major Instrumentation Award at Cal Poly in San Luis Obispo will benefit students and faculty at the institution as well as facilitating the establishment of new research partnerships with other universities and industry members. Collaboration with a broader research network will expand the study of existing and development of novel structural systems to improve building response for extreme loadings from natural hazards, specifically earthquakes.
